name: Economic Freedom of the World - Fraser Institute (2018)
title: Economic Freedom of the World - Fraser Institute (2018)
description:
The cornerstones of economic freedom are (1) personal choice, (2) voluntary exchange coordinated by markets, (3) freedom to enter and compete in markets, and (4) protection of persons and their property from aggression by others.

Individuals have economic freedom when property they acquire without the use of force, fraud, or theft is protected from physical invasions by others and they are free to use, exchange, or give their property as long as their actions do not violate the identical rights of others.

sources.name: Fraser Institute, Economic Freedom of the World (2018)
sources.additionalInfo:
The cornerstones of economic freedom are (1) personal choice, (2) voluntary exchange coordinated by markets, (3) freedom to enter and compete in markets, and (4) protection of persons and their property from aggression by others.

Individuals have economic freedom when property they acquire without the use of force, fraud, or theft is protected from physical invasions by others and they are free to use, exchange, or give their property as long as their actions do not violate the identical rights of others.

resources.path: Economic Freedom of the World - Fraser Institute (2018).csv

fields.name: Economic Freedom of the World (Fraser Institute (2018))
fields.description:
Economic freedom scoring is measured from 0 to 10 where 10 represents the maximum economic freedom, and 0 no economic freedom.

Economic freedom is measured by the Fraser Institute on the basis of the cornerstones of economic freedom: (1) personal choice, (2) voluntary exchange coordinated by markets, (3) freedom to enter and compete in markets, and (4) protection of persons and their property from aggression by others.

fields.name: Economic Freedom Rank (Fraser Institute, 2018)
fields.description:
Economic freedom ranking is measured from 1 to 162 (on the basis of 162 countries with data), where 1 represents the country with the highest economic freedom, and 162 the least.

Economic freedom is measured by the Fraser Institute on the basis of the cornerstones of economic freedom: (1) personal choice, (2) voluntary exchange coordinated by markets, (3) freedom to enter and compete in markets, and (4) protection of persons and their property from aggression by others.
